div.l: Vppon his Argument of herbergage
Wolle seide Salamōn in his langage
Ne preessepressepreesse not eủery man in thy house
For herborowynge be nyght is ꝑperlouse
Welle ought amān avisede for to be
Whom that he brynge in to his pⁱriuete
I pray to god to yeue me sorowe ⁊and care
Syn eủer that I hight hogge of ware
Herde I Miller bet I set awerke
He had a Iape of malice in the derke
But god forbede that we stynt here
And therfore yf ye vouchesafe to here
A tale of me that am a poure man
I wolle you telle as welle as I can
A litle Iape that fil in oure cite
Oure hoste answerd and seid I gᵃraunt it the
Nowe telle on Roger loke that hit be good
Fort many a pasty hast thou let blod
And many a Iack of dovir hast thou sold
That had be twyes hote and twyes cold
Of many pilgryme hast thou cristes curs
For of thy ꝑpercelly yet fare they the wors
Nowe telle on Roger by thy name
But I pᵃray the be not wroth for game
A mān may sey ful soth in game and play
Thou seist soth seyde Roger be my fey
But soth pley quade pley as the Flamynge seith
And therfore harry bally be thy feith
Be thou not wroth ar we departen here
Thogh that my tale be of an hostelere
But natheles I wilnot telle it yet
But or we depart I wis thou shalt be quyt
And therwithalle he lough and made chere
